thread.title: Um, how do I get out of my driveway?
thread.title_full: Um, how do I get out of my driveway?

title: Um, how do I get out of my driveway?
text:
A decision to place a power pole at the top of a private driveway has forced the homeowner to give up using his Mercedes sports car February 21, 2017 12:02pm Peter Gronow has trouble moving his Mercedes sports car out of his Drummoyne driveway because of an Ausgrid power pole. Picture: Craig Wilson Jim O’Rourke Inner West Courier Inner City Share Share on Twitter 
PETER Gronow bought his sleek black Mercedes Benz SLK 350 as a retirement present to himself. 
The former film and TV special effects whiz dreamt of touring the country with his wife Lisa in the 11-year-old convertible — until he was poleaxed by bureaucracy. 
Mr Gronow has been battling with electricity distributors Ausgrid about the location of a power pole at the front of his heritage-listed cottage in Dening St, Drummoyne since it was repositioned in 1982. 
It meant that he could not move his car out of the driveway without having to alter course to the left to get round the obstruction. Peter Gronow has damaged his Mercedes Coupe because he has to manoeuvre around an Ausgrid pole at the top of his driveway. Picture: Craig Wilson Source: News Limited 
To add to his misery, Ausgrid recently bolted a large steel brace — which juts out 15cms — around the pole making it even harder for the Gronow’s to enter and exit their property. 
“I’m in my 70s now and my wife and I are getting more and more nervous about getting our cars in and out of the driveway without banging into the pole,” Mr Gronow said. 
“It’s really affecting our enjoyment of the car. You just don’t want to risk moving it. Lisa refuses to use the driveway now. 
“I’ve already scratched one of the wheels on brickwork because I was concentrating on missing the pole. It’s costing me $200. I’m asking Ausgrid for the money.” The pole at the end of Peter Gronow’s driveway. Picture: Craig Wilson Source: News Limited The Ausgrid pole in front of Peter’s driveway. Picture: Craig Wilson Source: News Limited 
On January 18 Ausgrid installed a new pole about a metre away from the old one, and further away from the driveway entrance, but didn't to tell Mr Gronow when the old pole would be removed. 
After the Inner West Courier contacted Ausgrid, Mr Gronow received a notice that the pole will be taken down this week. 
“We understand that the temporary reinforcing support placed around the pole on Dening St was causing him difficulty, so we are replacing the pole and will remove the old pole and support as soon as possible,” an Ausgrid spokesman said. 
Ausgrid is also examining Mr Gronow’s application for compensation for damage to his vehicle’s wheel. Peter Gronow has to manoeuvre around an Ausgrid pole at the end of his driveway. Picture: Craig Wilson Source: News Limited
